d: A Handsome Atlas: Wildly Awesome Data Visualizations from the Nineteenth Century
n:
What's the story?
After the Civil War, the US doubled down on the Census, cranking out stunning maps, charts, and graphs.

About what?
Literally everything. Liquor, lumber, Methodists, malaria, insanity, Irishmen: everything!

Not Your Grandfather's Data Visualizations
Probably your great-great-grandfather's, though. But frankly: they're all awesome and modern.

Everything from wild maps to small multiples and chloropleths. And plenty of pie charts.

d: Teen Wolf Kink - DEREK/STILES AND DYLAN/TYLER H POST!
n:
derek is an EMT and stiles keeps getting hurt in bizarre ways he has no control over, such as a falling mattress or a chemical something in chem class and they keep calling ambulances and derek keeps showing up and he's like

"fucking are you kidding me? are you doing this on purpose? do you want to lose a limb? die? be permanently scarred?"

"surprising as it may seem, I'm really, REALLY not. ...though I would like your number. for--for emergency purposes?"

derek casually checks for a concussion

"i didn't even hit my head"

".... yet.... that you know of"



bonus points for working the mattress one in there in a semi-sane way.

d: How Patrick MacKenzie made me thousands of dollars « Kareem Mayan's Blog
The Mobile Playbook
Fixing A Broken User Experience | Smashing UX Design
n: Unless you’re developing completely new products at a startup, you likely work in an organization that has accumulated years of legacy design and development in its products. Even if the product you’re working on is brand spanking new, your organization will eventually need to figure out how to unify the whole product experience, either by bringing the old products up to par with the new or by bringing your new efforts in line with existing ones. A fragmented product portfolio sometimes leads to an overall broken user experience.
